title: SeaLink buoyed by Transit deal
text:
NRMA had acquired Manly Fast Ferry for an undisclosed sum from its founders in late 2017, which underlined the motoring group's plans to increase its exposure to tourism and as an extension to its roads-based core business.

SeaLink shares had been trading at $3.91 prior to the company entering a trading halt on October 7 ahead of the Transit Systems buyout deal.

Grant Thornton said in its independent expert report that since the 2018 indicative offer of $4.75 by the mystery bidder there had been some fresh uncertainties which had emerged, including a slowdown in international tourist numbers and a competitive tender for the Kangaroo Island ferry service initiated by the South Australian government.

It also pointed out that about 33 per cent of 2018-19 pro-forma revenue generated by Transit Systems is under contracts which expire before June 30, 2020. But Transit Systems had a strong track record of being able to both win new contracts and secure renewals.

On October 10, SeaLink revealed that Transit Systems had been awarded binding contracts to keep operating the Claremont and Marmion bus service in Perth for an extra 10 years to 2030, and had also won a new contract for Joondalup in Perth for 10 years.

Transit Systems operates 3129 buses across 40 different long-term contracts in Australia, London and Singapore, mainly on behalf of governments. It carries 344 million passengers annually.

SeaLink bought the marine division of Transit Systems, which operates passenger ferry and barge services in south-east Queensland and Gladstone, for $125 million in 2015.

The bus services operated by Transit Systems in Australia deliver solid and consistent income. The overall business generated revenue of $895 million in 2018-19 and earnings before interest and tax of $61 million on a pro-forma basis.

Transit Systems chairman Neil Smith will join the SeaLink board after the acquisition is completed and Transit chief executive Clint Feuerherdt will take over as boss of the whole company as SeaLink chief executive Jeff Ellison steps down after 21 years.

SeaLink is buying Transit Systems for an enterprise value of $635 million, plus an earn-out component of up to $63 million.

SeaLink expects to pull out between $4 million and $4.6 million in synergies by combining the two companies.
description: SeaLink shares have risen above both an independent expert valuation and a $4.75 indicative price in a 2018 mystery buyout proposal.
